text: you're silly boy I get to talk to Daniel
pretty much every day sometimes I'll
Skype on the weekends don't get to see
him and he'll get to see me he says hi
you know he's very exciting to hi mommy
and it's a good feeling but then he gets
distracted and runs off and does other
things I always tell him that I'll be
home soon that I love him and nothing's
changed that I'll be back going to war
doesn't mean losing touch with family
and friends anymore the Army's provide
us with this Morale Welfare and
Recreation Center and they have in their
like 40 computers and like 20 phones
soldiers he was email and Facebook to
keep in touch I think the best news that
I got through Facebook is that my son is
finally potty trained that was the best
lots of them go a step further and by an
international cell phone plan some of
them text friends and family in the US
throughout the day these were not things
that I that we deployed knowing i
deployed here with a lot of envelopes I
communicate with my wife twice daily I
like to let her know that I'm okay and I
like to hear her voice makes the days go
by a lot faster usually he wakes me up
in the morning he'll message me on my
phone then I come home from work and
then I usually wait up till about one
o'clock in the morning to get on the
webcam with him my wife will discuss her
her work day with me we talk about the
kids a lot especially Evelyn because
he's missing so much Oh baby
but so much connectedness doesn't always
make it easier on troops and their
families when you're used to hearing
from someone every day you get worried
when you suddenly don't one day I hadn't
heard from for three days and that's
really you know unusual or just you know
was just really off and so um I didn't
even want to come home cuz I didn't know
if they were going to be waiting here
for me so gets really hard for the
soldiers it can be tough for a different
reason in a way I kind of think I had
too much communication because the more
I know back home about what's going on
the more the less that I am
concentrating out here and that could
affect a lot of things and I could
potentially hurt me or other people
sometimes commanders and chaplains urge
soldiers to give the phone and facebook
arrest as often advise them to write but
writing is out today when email is much
faster this is the microwave generation
they need it and they need it fast
soldiers aren't allowed to use phones
while on patrol but in general the
military feels the benefits of instant
communication far outweigh the problems
and most deployed troops agree it's
bittersweet you know it's nice to see
him and be that involved in his life but
it's hard to know that he's growing up
without me there it's good to see but at
the same time it's it's still a little
heartbreaking at times
thank you thank you baby to be a good
boy okay
